awd_abstract_narration:
It is now a well-established fact that nucleons, protons and neutrons, are made up of more elementary particles called quarks. The measurements that will be carried out within this project will lead to a better understanding of nucleon structure and a better understanding of the effects of bound quarks moving at relativistic velocities. In particular, the proposed measurements will be used to extract detailed radial charge distributions of the proton and neutron, and will lead to a better understanding of how to interpret data from electron scattering experiments on nuclei. This project will train and support both undergraduate and graduate students, most of whom are minority students.  The program is highly interdisciplinary. It includes work with both hardware and software i.e., electronics, nuclear detector systems, optics, computer simulation, and data analysis. Students engaged in the program will work in a state-of-the-art facility and interact with scientists from other nationally recognized universities. These research activities will significantly impact the training of the students, preparing them for entering the STEM workforce of the 21st century.

This grant is to support research activities at North Carolina A&T State University on two programs. The first is the nucleon Form Factors (FF) program in Hall A at Jefferson Lab which is dedicated to the measurement of the neutron electromagnetic form factor ratio in double polarized, quasi-elastic scattering on 3He, and separately the neutron magnetic form factor in quasi-elastic scattering off the deuteron, both at high momentum transfer. The second is to measure the neutron Electric Form Factor at high momentum transfer from a deuterium target via recoil polarimetry in Hall C at Jefferson Lab. Elastic electromagnetic Form factors of the nucleon (proton or neutron) provide key information on the structure and the composition nature, of the nucleon, and the dynamics of quarks and gluons. For the FF program the group will build a photon detector array for the Gas Ring Imaging Cherenkov counter. For the experiment of Hall C, the group is building the polarimeter veto counters and the Delta-E detector arrays that identify the recoil proton from the neutron scattering events in the polarimeter analyzer.

por.por_cntn:
NSF awarded grant #1506363 of $214,999 in 2015 to the nuclear physics group at North Carolina A&T State University (NCA&T) to support its research activities at the Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility (Jefferson Lab). These activities include the nucleon Form Factors (FF) program and the precision Measurement of the Proton Elastic Cross Section at High Q2 (experiment E12-07-108) in Hall A.
These experiments investigate the fundamental issue of the electromagnetic structure of the neutron. The form factors have been studied in the past. However, this program extends these measurements to higher momentum transfers. Form factors of the nucleon (proton or neutron) provide critical information on the structure and the composition nature and the dynamics of its fundamental constituents, i.e., quarks and gluons.  A detailed and systematic study of the structure of the nucleon is of paramount importance for the understanding of nuclear matter
For the FF experimental program, the group collaborated with the University of William and Marry, Jefferson Lab, and James Madison University (JMU) to build the Gas Ring Cherenkov counter (GRINCH) for the BigBite spectrometer. The latter is vital in identifying the scattered particles and in measuring their energy and trajectory. The function of the gas Cherenkov detector is to provide good separation between pions and electrons in conjunction with the lead glass detector, which is essential for the success of the FF program. The group completed the construction of the GRINCH 510-channel Photon Detector Array and its magnetic shielding housing. The GRINCH detector system is fully assembled and is currently being tested at Jefferson Lab. The FF program will start taking data once it is scheduled by Jefferson Lab management. 
For experiment E12-07-108 in Hall A, an NC A&T Ph.D. student took a leading role in the data taking and analysis phases of the experiment. He was one of three Ph.D. students who were charged with analyzing the whole data set of the experiment. He used the Hall A analyzer software package to extract the elastic electron-proton cross-section using the Monte Carlo ratio method. In this method, the whole experiment is numerically simulated, and the simulation results are compared to the yields obtained from the measurements to extract the differential cross-section of the elastic electron-protons scattering. A total uncertainty of less than 2% was achieved for all Q2 points. The results of the elastic electron-proton cross-section for four points were compared to the world data with excellent agreement. These precise measurements offer an effective and powerful tool in constraining the existing phenomenological model. They are contributing to a better understanding of the nucleon structure and the fundamentals of the nuclear force. 
For both programs, the group participated actively in the experiment software development effort, simulation, data taking, and data analysis. This project trained, supported, and produced one Ph.D. student. It provided him with unique research opportunities in the field of experimental nuclear physics.
